div.head: "TO EMPIRE VIA DENISHWAI."
div.p: The appearance of Mr. Wilfred Scawen Blunt's "Secret History of the Occupation of Egypt" and the first anniversary of the Denishwai incident appear to have afforded further material for a fresh tirade by those who are anxious to prove, and would be proyd if they could do so, that England's administration of Egypt has been morally detrimental to both countries, and that we are occupying a country which it is our bounden duty to leave to its own devices. We do not refer to the Nationalist Press of Egypt, headed by Mustapha Kamel, for ever since the appearance of the English and French "Standards" we hąve been surfeited with "Denishwai," and our worthy contemporary appears to delight in vain reiterations on that subject. A bas les Anglais is the Pasha's motto, for he realises that as long as we remain here, his power and inflaence in the country will be infinitesimal. He should also realise, how. ever, that under no circumstances could we grant a constitution to a country which would give himself and his colleagnes any power. So long as the national party chooses to be represented by an irrational press, they must be content to be considered as pseudo-patriots.

We will refrain from again pointing out what immense benefits the greatest Pro-Consul of the era and his loyal supporters and assistants | have bestowed upon the country, but we might remark that having put our hand to the plough we are not going to turn back, until the task is completed. That Egypt is ready for selfgovernment is contended by few, and enge few are without exception Anglophobes.

In an article appearing in the "New Age," which we reproduce in another column, under | the heading of "To Empire vi& Denishwai", the writer endeavours to show that the British Administrators do not understand the temperament of the people they are governing. Such an accusation, however, is utterly confounded by the bond of friendship and genuine loyalty which exist throughout the vast British Empire. In every corner of the world mal. contents will be heard to give voice to imaginary grievancos, and unfortunately there are always | a few who take a pride in decrying their own nation, and to whom the word loyalty, the watchword of every healthy nation, has no meaning
"The Denishwai picnie", says the writer of | the article in question, "is diagnostic of the

most serious imperial disease - complacent | failure to understand." Accepting for the moment the hypothesis that the British officers implicated in the affair had caused the outrage by a lack of understanding, we still fail to see how such a conclusion can be drawn from the incident. Is the writer under the misap prehension that Egypt is governed by a mili tary administration ? As we have remarked before, it is possible that the death of Captain Bull and the brutal ill-treatment of his fellowofficers might have been avoided had they stuck to their guns and made a forcible resistance to the first onslaught, but this is very | doubtful and wonld most certainly have in volved seriously wounding not a few of the natives and possibly inflicting a certain loss of life on the village It was amply evidenced at the trial that the villagers had pre-arranged an attack on the officers ; and that five men could have defended themselves against such a mob is very, very doubtful, however bold a fase they might have offered. Reconciliation (for nothing) was the measure decided upon on the spur of the moment by the officer in command, and the result was as we know. It must be remembered, too, and this indeed, is the main point, that Lt. Col. Pine-Coffin understood at the moment of his arrival on the scene of the commencement of the attack, that Lt. Porter had accidentally shot the younded woman, whereas she had been shot by her fellow villagers at the moment when they wrested the gun away from Lt. Porter, who had put his gun at "safety,"

The real facts of the case, however, are not regarded by those whom we criticise, it being their ambition to prove to the world that our administration of this country is unjust, hogy they may rest assured that the distorted representations of the incidents apon which they base their arguments are recognised by the | large majority of those who take an interest
in this quarter of the globe. Both the Govern. ment and the Opposition have expressed in the

highest terms their recognition of the excel. | lence of the Anglo-Egyptian administration of the country, and the Seoretary for Foreign Affairs is one of the strongest supporters of Lord Cromer's policy. Were we to evacuate Egypt at the present moment we would incur the just blame of not only the majority of Egyptians, but also of the whole of Europe, whose interests we safeguard as well as those of the country and our own.

div.head: BIRTH, EVANS.--
div.p: On the 15th inst, at Alexandria, Mrs. E.C. Evans of a son.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and 0.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at half past four this afternoon,

div.head: Khedivial Mail Co.
div.p: The Khedivial Mail Steamship Company has purchased the Union Liner "Pretoria." This steamer will shortly leave London for Alexandria.

div.head: Found Drowned.
div.p: The body of a native, which has not as yet been identified, was taken from the Nile at Boulac yesterday, and has been transferred to hospital for post-mortem examination purposes. The body has the appearance of having been several days in the water.

div.head: Cerman Expansion.
div.p: With reference to the negotiations in progress for the arranging of Agencies in the Orient by the important Deutsches OrientHandels-Syndicat, we now learn that the contract has just been signed for its representation at Alexandria by Messrs Ludwig, Raudnitz, Bibs and Co.

div.head: Legislative Council.
div.p: It is considered probable that the meeting of the legislative Council, which was arranged for August, will not be held that month on account of the absence on leave of the greater part of the Councillors, which does not leave a sufficient number to form a quorum. The next meeting therefore will take place in the month of October.

div.head: British Consular Court.
div.p: Judgment was given yesterday afternoon at the British Consular Court, Alexandria, in the case of Parker against Thomas Hinshelwood Limited in favour of the defendant. The sum of £11. 13s. 4d, which the defendant had admitted was due to plaintiff, was ordered to be paid to the latter, the sum having been paid into court by. defendant. Both parties were ordered to pay their own costs.

div.head: Abydos Antiquities.
div.p: Yesterday the Duchess of Connaught inaugnrated the exhibition of Egyptian antiquities discovered at Abydos, Upper Egypt, by Pro. fessor Garstang and Mr. E. Harold Jones during the past winter. The exhibition is being held in the rooms of the Society of Antiquaries, Burlington-house, Piccadilly, W. The exhibition will be open untilthe 30th inst.

div.head: Kassala Forests.
div.p: In order to encourage agriculture and help the reclaiming of waste and forest lands, the authorities of the Province of Kassala have offered 600 feddans of forest land for free cultivation. 300 feddans have already been taken up by one of the leading citizens of Kassala. The couditions stipulated are that the tenant must clear at least 100 feddans each year and put it in a condition suitable for cultivation. The Government, on its part, agrees to grant him free use of the land for six years. No rents, or taxes of any sort will be collected. At the termination of the six years, the land will revert to the Government.

div.head: The Marsasdirocco Reefs.
div.p: About a year ago a Prince Liner from Alexandria went ashore on the Marsascirocco Reef at Malta, and last week the German steamer Wellgunde, with a cargo of wheat from Constantinople, struck during the night on the same spot. But for the Admiralty. Malta would be almost helpless in such emergencies, but the speedy and powerful naval dockyard tugs were soon despatched by Rear-Admiral Fisher. when news of the disaster was brought by the chief officer of the Wellgunde to the Custom House, at six o'clock. The sea was very calm, but the night was very hazy. No one was injured. The vessel is being lightened, and is expected to get off soon.

div.head: Egyptian Music Halls.
div.p: According to the "Daily Chronicle" an extraordinary organisation has been discovered in Italy for the export of Neapolitan debutantes for Egyptian music halls. Our London contemporary says :- "A big Sicilian secret agency for the white slave traffic, managed by the Mafia, and having its headquarters in the City of Catania, has been exposed by the police. Sixty arrests have been made. The agency has been in full working order for several years. Shiploads of young Italian girls from the Southern provinces have been transported to Cairo and other towns of the Orient under cover of false passports. In appears that the traffic was greatly facilitated through the unlimited demand for Neapolitan débutantes for Egyptian music-halls.".

div.head: New Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: As we have previously announced, the new Alhambra Theatre is to be inaugurated this evening with the representation of the "Geisha" staged by the Lombardo troupe, the play commencing at 9-15 p.m. The Lombardo troupe is well-known to Alexandrians and established a well-deserved reputation here last year, but we notice several changes in the caste and · hope for the improvements which we pointed out as necessary in our criticisms of last year's performances. Mimosa San is to be played to-night by Miss 0. Rosalin, and her sister, Miss J. Rosalin, of both whom we have excellent reports, will take the part of Molly Seamore, while Miss G. Paroli will represent the "cheeky" little midshipman, Tommy Stanley. Urbano is still the leader of the troupe and we are to have a repetition of his inimitable representation of Wun-Hi, in which he invariably invokes roars of laughter, and the parts of Roggy Fairfax and Dick Cunningham have been entrusted to Messrs E. Baldi and E. Sacchi, respectively.

div.head:
MR. LAMBERT'S RESIGNATION.
QUESTIONS IN PARLIAMENT,
MR HILL'S APPOINTMENT.
div.p: Sir Edward Grey replying to Mr. Robertson, concerning the retirement of Mr. Lambert, said that there was no ground for reflection on Mr. Dunlop's conduct. In view of the growing demand on the English side of the school it was necessary to promote an English professor to the vacancy.

LONDON, July 16. House of Commons. In reply to Mr. Rutherford who declared that Mr. Lambert's resignation was due to differences with Mr. Dunlopand demanded Mr. Dunlop's resignation, Sir E. Grey said that he understood that M. Lambert resigned in consequence of a misunderstanding with the Ministry of Instruction with reference to leave of absence. In view of | the growing demand to enter the English side of the school the Egyptian Government promoted one of the English professors to the vacancy. There was no ground for the suggestion that the appointment was contrary to the spirit of the Anglo-French agreement of 1904, and there was no reason whatever for | the reflection cast on Mr. Dunlop. (Reuter)
"Al-Minbar asserts that it has learnt from a reliable sourse that Mr. Dunlop's resignation was received in Cairo by wire two days ago.
On enquiry at the British Agency this morning we were informed that nothing is known there about the resignation of Mr. Dunlop, which appears to be an invention of the Nationalist Press.

The "Egyptian Standard" seizes the opportunity of the rumoured resignation of Mr. Dunlop, as given by our contemporary, to indulge in a series of reflections, of which the following is an extract :- This assertion does not surprise is in the least. We had foreseen it and foretold it. For, after an open blunder it is rare if a British official - even if he be paid by Egypt for services he never rendered her - remains long in the post he took no pains to cover with glory.
Naturally it will be stated that reasons of health dictated his resignation. May his health improve. It is our earnest wish. But let it improve in England and not in Egypt.
And once again, in the name of the whole Egyptian people and nation, we repeat the national claims : Let nobody replace Mr. Dunlop.
The moment for the abolition of the Educational Advisership has arrived. It could not be more favourable.

div.head: SHIPPING IN EGYPT.
div.p: According to the Statistical return of Navigation in the ports of Egypt issued by the Statistical Department of the Finance Ministry, during 1906 there were altogether 3,243 steamers, and 1,913 sailing vessels entered with a registered gross tonnage of 7,887,558 for the former, and 231,147 for the latter. Of these ships Alexandria's entries amount to 1,958 and 884 respectively, Port Said 885 and 364, Suez 266 and (), and other ports 136 and 665. It will be seen from these figures that Alexandria receives considerably more than half the shipping of Egypt, the grand totals being as follows :-No. of vessels 5,156 with gross tonnage 8,118,705 and net tonnage 5,006,194 ; of which Alexandria 2,842 vessels, gross tonnage 5,199,864, net tonnage, 3,242,278; Port Said 1,249 vessels, gross tonnage 2,357,246, net tonnage 1,413,701 ; Suez 266 vessels, gross tonnage 382,740, net tonnage 225,326 ; and other ports 799 vessels, gross tonnage 178,855, net tonnage 124,889.

Out of the grand total of 5,156 vessels 1,648 (not for short of one-third, emanated from the British Empire, 791 of which number were from the British Isles. 718 steamers and 1,566 sailing vessels were registered from Turkey, France sent 213 steainers. and Italy 203, while Austria-Hungary comes next with 129 steamers and Russia with 122. There were only 39 vessels from Germany, 36 of which were entered at Alexandria. Classified by nationality (the above figures being accord. ing to the countries of origin) the numbers of steamers were : - British 1,633 ; Greek 324 ; French 256 ; Austro-Hungarian 241 ; Italian 227; Russian 156 ; German 111 ; Turkish 110; and Belgian 62.
The vessels cleared from the ports of Egypt during 1906 were 3,231 steamers and 1,725 sailing vessels, with a total gross tonnage of 8.085.007 and net tonnage of 4.978.932.

div.head: VAGABONDS AND HASHISH DENS.
div.p: A detachment of special police were very active yesterday in Cairo making 30 arrests o loafers and vagabonds during the day. So much has been said and written lately about ruffianly Berberins who parade the streets o the Capital, molesting pedestrians, that it is pot surprising to learn that among these 30 arrests twenty were Berbering. The special police also made a descent on two hashish smoking dens in the Mousky, belonging to French subject, named Murdo, and effected the arrest of two men, who were recently expelled from the country : one is an Italiar and the other a Greek.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "Imperial Prince," with passenger and a general cargo, left Malta on the 15t1 inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria oi Friday next.

div.head:
THEKHEDIVE'S RAILWAY.
MARIOUT DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: The railway, which the Khedive is building through the Mariout district, is a remarkable example of his Highness's enterprise and sagacity and deserves to rank as one of the most noteworthy undertakings in the Egypt of to-day. It is not long since the country between Alexandria and the Tripolitan frontier was almost unknown. Few Europeans had ever traversed it, and the Bedouins of the Awlad Aly tribe, who dwelt there, were notorious for their lawlessness. A few years ago the Khedive's attention as an agricolturist was drawn to this neglected part of Egypt, and his investments in land there induced him to study the means of locomotion. His Highness first constructed a road, which gave way to a line of light railway, which subsequently was transformed to the existing normal gauge line, so familiar to excursionists from Alexandria to Kingi Mariout, who go thither in the spring to enjoy the wonderful wealth of flowers that floorish so luxuriantly after the rains of winter The railway was begun seven years ago and has been carried on continually westward until at the present time railhead is now 174 kilometres from the Alexandrian terminus of the line at Wardian. From the end of the line his Highness has constructed an excellent load as far as Mersa Matrouh, 287 kilometres from Alexandria. A road was originally made along the route now followed by the line, but as the railway is pushed forward the former means of communication, being no longer necessary, is not kept in repair. The system of construction is twofold. The normal gauge extends 105 kilometres from Wardian. At Taba dul (Arabic "transhipment",) between Al Amied and Sidi Abdul Rahman, the work of changing from the narrow to the broad gauge is proceeding at the rate of 540 metres daily. The railhead of the narrow gauge line is now at 13 kilometres west of Dabbah, or 69 kilometres from Tabadul, and 113 kilometres remain to be laid before Mersa Matrouh is reached. At the present time the rails in hand amount to 150 kilometres of broad and 10 of narrow gauge. The railway will not stop at Mersa Matrouh but will go on to Sidi Berani and thence to the frontier at Solloum. At the present time from the terminus at Wardian to railhead a vast amount of work is in hand. At Wardian a new terminus is being built, which will cover twenty feddans. It is to be fitted with a restaurant and all the other appurtenances of an up-to-date first class railway station. Next year the Khedive's line will be brought into connection with the passenger traffic of the Egyptian Government Railway's terminus at Alexandria by means of a line from Moueslah, the junction near Mex, to Bab-el-Ghedid station. There is now a connection for goods traffic between the two railway systems. A new station is to be built at Moueslah junction in the course of this year in order to facilitate the connection and in January next it is hoped that the first through passenger train from Bab-el-Ghedid to El Amrieh will begin to run daily. A new iron bridge over the Mareotic Canal at Mexis nearly finished for the broad gauge trains. Its cost was £2,500. A large engine house has just been completed there. It is not only on the Alexandrian side of the line that such I progress is in evidence, but all along the 161 kilometres of railway from Wardian to Debba the signs of development continue without a break. As soon as the causeway between Lake Mareotis and the Salt Lake has been passed, the line from the first three stations, Abd-elKader, Amrieh, and Kingi Mariout, has | recently been endowe? with an expensive new German system of semaphores for signalling. Every ten kilometres along the line well-built quarters have been erected for the gangers to live in. At each station there are separate platforms, for passengers and goods. The Khedive is not merely going to run a line through the district, but his Highness intends to run branches to suitable spots where there are prospects of developing the country. For example at Kingi Mariont a turn-table for engines has | been put into position as there is to be a branch Aline from that station to the sea coast, as in time a seaside resort for Alexandrians may come into being there. Further on at Gherbanyet station a new siding has just been built for the transport of gypsum. His Highness owns about four hundred feddans of gypsum-bearing land in the immediate neighbourhood. At Hammam a large condensing station has only been finished a few days ago at a cost of £3,500 and a similar installation is to be erected at Dabba. The water, although excellent for drinking purposes at Hammam is so much impregnated with lime that condensers are necessary if the boilers are not to be impaired. The progress of the line necessitates the sinking of wells, and a great number have been made by the Khedive. At Hawarieh a well has just been sunk 35 metres deep at the cost of £800.

It is not necessary to enter into any minute detail as to the many other subsidiary works which such a gigantic andertaking entails. The line has already proved a success and fully justified his Highness's foresight in opening up this hitherto neglected part of Egypt. All along the coast there are signs that once the country was populated and the remains of ancient cities are numerous, such as Taposiris and Saint Menas, and others sites further to the West.

Through the Khedive's initiative the prosperity of the country is returning. In ancient times the wines of Mariout were celebrated throughout the ancient world, and at Kingi | Mariout his Highness has succeeded in growling fortyfeddang of excellent grapes. The I barley of the country is famous and olives find a congenial soil here. Now that the railwa secures easy communication with Alexandri there is every reason to believe that the ancier prosperity of Mariout will return, and the firs who recognised the potentialities of th: renaissance was the Khedive, whose labour are now beginning to bear fruit, as the financis details of the railway, which we will deal wit in another article, will amply prove.

div.head:
THE YEMEN RISING.
ACTIVITY OF THE REBELS.
div.p: Aden, July 9. Turkish deserters continue to come her lamenting their loss. In a previous letter stated that Mellah district was captured b the rebels. Several days after the capture this place, four battalions of Turkish troop arrived at Mellah from Faez Rudda and othe places, only to find the place desolate.

The rebels are reported to have taken b storm An Nadhira, a Turkish district abou one day's journey from the Turkish distric Kataba, poorly garrisoned by Turkish troop: but after an engagement, they were dislodged and fighting is still going on. Turkish rein forcements have arrived in from Kataba, Rudd and other places. The rebels are reported t number 4,000 strong. No details have yet bee received

Some 150 Turkish troops left Kataba wit ammunition to reinforce the garrison at Na dhirra, before the arrival of the reinforcement Before reaching Nadhira, they were me by the rebels, who engaged the troop: plundered the ammunition, killing abou 80 from the troops and wounding about 40 the rest of the troops fled with the wounde to Kataba.

div.head: FIRE IN CAIRO.
div.p: On Tuesday morning a fire broke out i Sharia Mohamed Aly, Darb el Menaguemal to which the Fire Brigade was called at 11.5 a.m. On the call being given three steamer were immediately on the spot, which adjoir the fire station, and in spite of the powerfu hold already obtained by the fames, con batted the flames with great success consi ering the extreme difficulty of the approache and the low pressure obtainable from th hydrants. Such was the violence of the on break, that two floors of the tenement hous in which the fire originated were practical burnt out, and the firemen had all their wor cut out to save the remainder of the hous and limit the extent of the fire, which threat ened to spread in the direction of th Police School at the back, in the vicinity which was an establishment with a large sto of inflammables : a corner of these premise which were constructed of wood, had alread caught fire, but was saved by prompt measure taken by the brigade. * Enormous difficulty attended the suppressic of the fire owing principally to the extrem difficulty of access from the front, and th wind which caused a forced draught from tl back in the open space surrounding the Poli School. A steamer was placed in this ope space and played on the burning building & well as the water pressure would permit: tw other steamers in Sharia Mohamed Ali di their best, and after some three hours har work the fire was got under control. T Brigade did excellent work and by their d voted efforts saved almost the entire quart from devastation, and they are to be congra tulated on their perseverance and fearle: energy in combating the flames.

Four flats in the house where the fire brok out were completely gutted; four other apar ments were considerably damaged by hex and water, and when our representative visite the scene of the outbreak it was indeed on of devastation, with the approaches flooded b water in which were floating charred rafte and all the debris resulting from a fiero outbreak. The outbreak is attributed to kitchen chimney, but no reliable informatic is forthcoming in this respect.

div.head: AMERICANS IN EGYPT.
div.p: There are numbers of Armenians and Syrians from the United States, who have settled in Egypt and other parts of the Ottoman Empire, after having obtained American citizenship. All of these will be affected by the new citizenship law which came into effect on July 1st.
The provision of the new law which is responsible for their worries is that reading as follows:

"When any naturalised citizen shall have resided for two years in a foreign-State from which he came, it shall be presumed that he has ceased to be an American citizen, and his place of general abode shall be deemed his place of residence during the said years.".

It is provided that such presumption may be overcome on the presentation of satisfactory evidence before a diplomatic or consular officer of the United Sttases, but thousands of these American citizens born in the Ottoman Empire, are fearful they will be unable to present "satisfactory" evidence within the meaning of the law. A large majority of them never intend to return to America, and as passports henceforth will be issued only within the confines of the United States, instead of at Embassies and consulates as heretofore, these

subjects" of Uncle Sam who have settled down to spend the afternoon of their lives in the land of their birth are filled with concern lest the days of their American citizenship may be nearing a definite end. | It would be conferring a genuine boon upon a large number of very worthy naturalised citizens who find it convenient for one reason or another to live in the Levant, if the State Department at Washington would issue some kind of unambiguous statement covering their case,

div.head:
WEIGHTS AND MEASURES.
ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY'S SCHEME
div.p: An interesting article appears in the June Monthly Journal" of the British Chamber of Commerce for Egypt on weights and measures in Alexandria, in which the writer remarks that thanks to the provisions of the Capitulations, a Municipality in this country has no control over a European retailer's weights and measures. It is true that if such a shopkeeper be found in the possession of false weights or measures he can be prosecuted in the Mixed Tribunals, but, as the maximum fine is only the nominal sum of £1, it is obvious that the penalty does not act as a deterrent.

About two years ago, the Alexandria Municipality, in consequence of the numerous complaints on the subject, decided to institute as an experiment a system of voluntary inspection under which retailers could have their weights verified bye the anthorities and certified as correct. This scheme was placed before the Ministry of the Interior who replied asking the Municipality cot to move further in the matter for the moment, as a much wider scheme was then under the consideration of the Government. The scheme is, apparently, still under consideration, for nothing tangible has been done during the intervening two years, and the Municipality has, therefore, decided not to wait any longer but to proceed on its own account.

It is proposed to distribute thoroughout the town standard weights and measures in kilogrammes okes and metres) which will be under the control of Municipality employés. The public will then be invited to have their purchases weighed or measured, as the case may be, with a view to checking the retailer's figures. No charge will be made to the public provided the weight does not exceed 10 kilos, but, in order to protect the service against abuse, a charge of one millieme per kilo will be made for each kilo above ten.

Another part of the scheme consists in the stamping of shopkeepers' weights and measures, and the continued inspection of the same afterwards. For this purpose, in view of the Capitulations, it will be necessary for all retailers wishing to avail themselves of the privilege to sign an agreement authorizing the Municipal officials to enter their premises at all times to verify the weights. On this undertaking being given, the shopkeeper will be allowed to advertise the fact that his premises are under Municipal inspection so far as his weights and measures are concerned. The stamping in the first instance will, probably, be done free of charge.

It is admitted that the scheme is only a tentative one, and is merely put forward by way of experiment. Although many difficulties may crop up, which at the present time cannot be foreseen, the idea seems to us to be a good one and a distinct step in the right direction The success of the whole indertaking lies prac tically in the hands of the public If the latter retuse to deal with shops not under Municipa inspection, it will not be long before many o the abuses at present prevalent will have entirely disappeared.

div.head:
GHIZEH ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS.
REPORT FOR 1906.
div.p: A small Museum of Zoology has been started in connection with the Gardens, and is housed for the present in the old watchmen's rooms in the north-east corner of the grounds, near the lion house and African aviary. The specimens are being arranged in two series : for instruction and for research.
Eventnally, it is hoped, they may be arranged in three series : -

1st. For instruction to the general public : every specimen exhibited should have its definite purpose, should be good of its kind, should have all available skill and care spent upon its preservation and method of exhibition, and the number of specimens exhibit ed should be strictly limited according to the space available ; few things are so depressing to the ordinary visitor to a Museum, whether of natural history or other objects, as long series of exibits all, from his point of view, practically the same; this is particularly felt by that large number of visitors to Museums who can spare but a short time for their visit.
2nd. For instruction to students, and all such other visitors who may have the time or inclination to see more than is provided by the first series of specimens.

3rd. For study and research by naturalists working at the various branches of zoology this series should be large numerically, but stored in boxes or cabinets, which both on account of expense as well as convenience of access should occupy as small a space as is compatible with their proper classification and preservation from damp, insects etc. * No specimens should be admitted into the collection unless they fulfill one of the following conditions
S enaste 1st. Are of such spectacular or lotal interest that they are calculated to give ocular instruction to the ordinary visitor.
2nd: Illustrate the fauna of Egyptsand the Sndan.
3rd. Are of use to the staff of the menagerie for purposes of reference to points of anatomy, nomenclature, variation, etc. OF
On the 31st December 1906 the collection comprised -
Exhibition Series, 9 Mammals, 17 Birds, 2 Reptiles, 4 Fish, also some Horns, Eggs, Coral, etc.
Study Series, 37 skins of Mammals, 100 skins of Birds

div.head:
THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
TROUBLES IN CAIRO.
div.p: Yesterday the firm of Khalifa Naggar of Cairo and a number of other brms suspended payment. It is boped that if the creditors exercise forbearance the serious consequences of these disasters will be greatly mitigated. We are informed that if the case of Khalifa Naggar be carefully handled, the creditors should get a great proportion of their money back. It is said that the liabilities of Khalito, Naggar amounted to more than half a million on the 14th inst. In the case of Sabal Brothers their assets are reported to be superior to their liabilities. The firms, who have suspended payment besides that of Naggar are Palacci Fils, Haïm and Company, Sahal Brothers, Behor Hamaoui and Sons, Zananiri Elias.
The "Bourse Egyptienne" gives the following details :
La question des tirages à trois mois sur les Banques de Manchester et de Londres est toujours en voie de s'arranger de manière à avoir le moins de répercussion possible snr la place.

En ce qui concerne le dépôt du bilan de la maison Naggar, faisons observer que ce dépôt est dans le programme de l'accord intervenu et permettra une liquidation lente, de nature à ménager les intérêts des tiers.

Le dépôt du bilan de la Maison Khalifa Naggar a eu lieu hier à 1 h. p.m. Le passit s'élevait à 666,522 L.E. à la date du 14 juillet écoulé, non compris le change. Le bilan se compose d'un compte en arabe et d'une dizaine d'annexes. Voici quelques chiffres : Avances sur valeurs publiques 27.783,148 P.T. (no 1); avances sur valeurs publiques compte | reports 32,559,755 (no 2); comptes-courants créditeurs 2,123,747 ; compte coupons 8,494 ; effets à recevoir 54,325 ; administrations, banques 2,023,439 ; circulation comptes francs 10,367,031 ; eirculation comptes sterling 14,465,086 ; titres en portefeuille (Ismaïlia) 4,935 L.E. dont 1,745 actions Windsor Hotel et 2,812 parts fondateurs du même.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MOTOR TRACTION CO.
div.p: An ordinary and extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Egyptian Motor Traction Company was held at the offices of the Chairman of the Board of Di. rectors at Alexandria yesterday. It was unanimously decided that the proposal of a European automobile manufacturer be accepted, whereby two new cars should be added to the Company's stock. Each of these cars will hold from 26 to 30 passengers. They will be ready in a few months' time, when this Company's service at Alexandria will be resomed.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The following decisions were approved at yesterday's meeting of the Council of Ministers at San Stefano :
To release Almaz El Hana, wrongly sentenced to 6 months' imprisonment.
To expropriate land for the enlargement of Asfun, El Fadilia, El Kalabia, and Al Mialla canals in Keneh Province.
To expropriate land for the construction of 6 agricultural roads and 24 small bridges in El Badari, Abu Tig and the southern part of Assiout Districts.
To sanction regulations for destruction of locusts in the Sudan and for prohibition of the sale of alcoholic liquors in the same.
To reduce the school fees of the pupils of Esna, Edfa, and Assnan Primary Schools from L.E. 5 to L.E. 3 per year.
To commission Mr. - Maitland to proceed to Paris to study the drainage system of that city.
To permit the purchase of 2 or 3 tugs by the Coast Guard Service for use at Port Said.

To open a credit of L.E. 1,273 for the installation of water-pipes in El Zamalik lands, Giza province ; another credit of L.E. 5,000 for the Cotton Worm in Egypt; and a further credit of L.E. 300 to purchase land for the erection of a house for the Mudir of Kena Province.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mr. Favarger, F. S. A., F. R. I. B. A., leaves Alexandria for England to-day, having completed his inspection of the new building of Victoria College
The rumour that Dr. Bitter has tendered his resignation is stated to be incorrect

Mr. Charles Edward Hamilton, fellow of the Royal Geographical Society, whose death was reported in London last week will be remembered as the explorer who, half hanged by Arabs in the Sudan, escaped through the breaking of the camel rope by which he had been suspended. Mr. Hamilton accompanied Sir Richard and Lady Burton on one of their expeditions, and saved Lady Burton from being killed by a lion. Mr. Hamilton was the author of several books of travel."

div.head:
AUSTRIA AND ITALY.
KING RECEIVES MINISTERS.

div.p: Baron. Aebrenthal and Signor Tittoni spent the day with the King and Queen at Racconigi. Baron Aehrenthal in the morning accom panied the King on a motor trip. (Reuter,
The King has received Baron d'Aerenthal and M. Tittoni. The two Ministers have declar ed thomselves to be in agreement on all points
(Havas)

div.head:
AUSTRIAN EMPEROR'S
JUBILEE.
OLD AGE PROPOSAL.

div.p: M. Lueger will propose in the House a credit of 100,000,000 crowns for assurance against old age and ill-bealth, on the occasion of the jubilee of the Emperor's 60th year of reign.
(Havas)

div.head:
ASSASSINATION IN TIFLIS.
SERIOUS LOSS OF LIFE.

div.p: General Alikhanoff, the ex-Governor of the town, a General and his wife, General Glieboff and a soldier have been killed by bombs in the street.
(Reuter)

div.head:
HOUSE OF LORDS.
BILLS FROM THE COMMONS.

div.p: Lord Camperdown drew attention to the lack of time given to the Lords to deal with bills which had passed the Commons. Lord Lansdowne declared that the Lords would not submit to having many bills forced upon them during last fortnight of the session. They would insist upon legislation being decently and deliberately conducted.
(Reuter)

div.head:
EXPLOSION ON THE "GEORGIA."
EIGHT FATALITIES RECORDED.

div.p: An explosion of an 8 inch turret gun has occurred on board the battleship "Georgia" whilst at target practice at Provincetown. 17 men have been injured, 5 of whom have died.
(Reuter)

8 men are dead owing to the gun explosion on board the "Cleorgia," and 6 are not expected to recover. It appears that a 200 pound charge was being lifted, preparatory to insertion in the 'gun, when two, seamen noticed that the covering was sinoaldered and shouted warning, but it was too late for the men in the turret to Ivo ise the meaning. (Reuter)
are

div.head:
JAPAN AND KOREA.
VISCOUNT HAYASHI'S VISIT,

div.p: Viscount Hayashi's coming has caused consteration in the Palace. The Emperor is dis trustful of the Japanese soldiers and is trying to introduce Korean guards. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
KOREAN DELEGATE DIES.

div.p: M. Tchun, one of the Korean delegates, has died anddanly. He has been huried here. (R)
M. Fallières gave a luncheon to the officers of the American squadron which is at Brest. Cordial toasts were exchanged and the old-time friendship of the two nations recalled (Havas)
The Senate is sitting as a High Court to try the ex-minister, Signor Nasi, for malversation during his term of office. Signor Nasi has been arrested
(Reuter)
(Havas)
M. Poubelle is dead.
South Africans beat Yorkshire by 5 wickets.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE BOURSE AND BANKING CO.OF EGYPT LIMITED.
div.p: Monsieur l'Editeur de "l'Egyptian Gazette"

En Ville. L'Association des Courtiers en valeurs dans sa séance d'hier a pris une détermination au sujet du règlement des actions de cette Société, qui à mon avis peut engager les diverses agences dans leurs rapports mutuels, mais qui n'a aucune valeur en ce qui concerne leurs rapports avec leurs clients vendeurs de ces mêmes actions. Comment peuton obliger un actionnaire qui est vendeur d'une certaine quantité d'actions en vertu d'un contrat fait au mois de Février, de se conformer à une décision prise an mois de Juillet ? Dans aucun pays du monde la loi n'a d'effet rétroactif, et je ne vois trop quel motif légitime l'on pourrait invoquer pour léser d'une façon si manifeste les intérêts des actionnaires.

Il est de notoriété publique qu'à un certain moment les actions de la Bourse and Banking ont été poussées par les agissements de certains spéculateurs à des prix nullement en rapport ni à la valeur intrinsèque du titre, ni à la situation du marché | financier, qui donnait déjà des signes non équivoques de crise. Il résulte en outre de source autorisée, que les paquets d'actions achetés par ces spéculateurs étaient cédés par MM. les administrateurs à des cours variant entre £ 1 et 23. Par la combinaison adoptée par l'Association des Courtiers ce sont donc ces Messieurs qui viendraient à bénéficier d'un arrangement auquel en toute équité ils ne devraient pas participer. Il ne faut pas oublier que ces Messieurs, par leur coupable négligence ont permis qu'une Société fondée au mois de Février, I'put gaspiller dans l'espace de 4 mois un capital de £ 130,000. Eh ! bien, ne vous semble-t-il pas étrange que le jour que l'on nous propose un arrangement ils soient les premiers à en tirer un avantage ? En effet, supposez un souscripteur qui a vendu 100 Actions au prix de £ 13 ; par l'arrangement décidé il ne toucherait que £ 37). Par contre, un administrateur qui s'est défait de ses actions, ou du moins d'une bonne partie, à un cours minimum de £ 13, touche en vendant 100 Actions une somme de £ 75. Je trouve que l'Association des courtiers, avant de prendre une délibération aussi grave, aurait dû s'assurer que les administrateurs ne profitaient pas d'un seul centime d'un état de choses dont ils sont seuls responsables, et pour lequel dans tout autre pays, ils auraient peut-être encourus les rigueurs de la loi. Veuillez agréer, Monsieur l'Editeur, etc.

div.head: A COPTIC GRAMMAR
div.p: The Coptic Grammar of Father A. Mallon of the Society of Jesus, å description of which was given in " The Egyptian Gazette" some two years ago, has met with such success that a second edition has been called for, and has qust been published by the Imprimerie Catholique of Beyrout. The new edition does not Hiffer very widely from its predecessor, but Pére Mallon has embodied all the corrections und valuable additions which Coptic scholars have in their reviews or by personal communimation suggested to him. The grammar and the supplementary Chrestomathy of specimens of Coptic literature is founded upon the Boharic variant of the Coptic language, and to prevent confusion in the student's mind between its vocabulary and the Sahidic, everything concerning the latter has in this edition been separated, and is printed together in the portion of the Grammar treating of Morphology. For a full knowledge of the Sahidic, however, scholars will turn to the Coptic Grammar, of Steindorf, which is based upon the Sahidic: "The Chrestomathy of texts is in the new edition augmented by no less than 35 pages presenting the history of Joseph as contained Gin Exodus 39-44. This is given from a Paris manuscript, but that is carefully collatmed with another at Rome, and all the variants given. For this comparison Père Mallon is indebted to Professor M. J. Guidi, who has for the purpose devoted much time to this work in the Vatican library. The most praiseworthy portion of the supplement to the grammar is the splendid bibliography extending to over 50 pages and referring to every treatise, essay and monogrraph upon every dialect of Coptic; this is undoubtedly the most complete catalogue of Coptic studies in existence. In cases where an "editio princeps' of great importance is specified, such as the "Acta Pauli" of Carl Schmidt at Heidelberg, the most important reviews of the edition are also enumerated. This bibliography indicates the existence of Coptic manuscripts in out ofthe-way places, inaccessible to European stirdents. Forinstance, it appears that a long Coptic papyrus containing the laws and rules governing the great monastery of Saint Phoibanon at Jémé is now in the Museum of the University of Kazan. Whilst the grammar is principally one for the Boharic dialect, specimens of texts in other versions are given, and are excellently arranged for the purpose of comparison. Thus, part of the 5th chapter of Zachariah is printed in the Sahidic and Achminic as well as Boharic; Isaiah 1 in the latter and in Sahidic and Fayoumic are provided, whilst portions of Isaiah 23 are given in Boharic and Memphitic. A vocabulary of all Sahidic words to be found in the specimen texts of that dialect printed in the Grammar is provided, as well as the very complete Boharic dictionary printed as accompaniment to the Grammar.

Whilst it is reasonable to suppose that the richest part of the harvest of Egyptian, Greek and Latin papyri has now been gathered, there can be no doubt but that thousands of Coptic manuscripts will yet be discovered in Egypt, preserved in the ruins of old houses or in the cemeteries of Christian Egypt, and anyone desiring to acquire an adequate knowledge of Coptic to edit and study the new texts, which will certainly in many cases embody most valuable literature, cannot do better than master Père Mallon's excellent grammar.
div.note: * "Grammaire Copto, avee Chrestomathe, Vocabulaire et Bibliographe" Beyrouth Imprimerie Catholique 1907. par . J. Malcon S.J.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN NOVEL.
div.p: "THE GATES OF KAMT" (BARONESS Orozv.)

In this new novel by the author of "The Scarlet Pimpernel," we are taken into a very wonderful country indeed, among the lost people of ancient Egypt, who are supposed by the author not to have perished from the face of the earth, but to have a kingdom of their own to-day. This kingdom, "the world forgetting, by the world forgot," is supposed to be situated among steep mountains beyond the inaccessible sand dunes that surround the Libyan desert.

The period that undoubtedly followed the | death of Quen Neib-akrib and the close of the sixth dynasty is practically a blank to Egypt ologists. It marks the elose of the old empire, strangers appear to have overrun Egypt, and for four centuries the history of ancient Egypt is unknown. Neither tombs not temples mark the changes and vicissitudes which befel this wonderful people who built the great pyramids and carved the Sphinx. | It is the descendants of those people, retaining their ancient langnage and customs, among whom the reader is introduced. He is not carried back into the past, the past is brought to him. Two young and adventurous spirits who had been school chums, after much adventure and hardship, finally pass the I gates of Kamt and discover these people.

The father of one of these young men had been a celebrated Egyptologist and had devoted himselt particulary to searching for traces of these lost people. He had reconstructed the blank page in Egyptian bistory after a theory of his own, which the son proved a correct one, though it had been greatly scoffed at, and he had also reconstructed the language of ancient Kamt, and this he taught to his son and his son's friend, together with the hieroglyphic and muneiform writings of the ancient Egyptians. He spent his life in these researches and passed a rich heritage of knowledge to his son. By means ol an ancient papyrus left him by his father the son locates the newer kingdom of the ancient people and finally enters into its wonders and glories with his friend

Knowledge of the language and of manners and customs stands the adventurers in good stead. The yonng Egyptologist persuaded the people of Kamt that he has been sent to rule among them by the great god Ra himself. He becomes engaged to marry the widowed Queen of Kamt, but falls in love with a princess, her niece. Bat one must go to the book itself for the story, which is of absorbing interest and worked ont with such a cleverness of detail that it seems as real as some of the romances of Jules Verne. There are gorgeous descriptions of fêtes and festivals and sacrifices, the stately pageantry of ancient Egypt passes in all its solemn glory before the mental vision, and every page is full of color. Scarcely since Flaubert have ancient people heen so realistically pictured (Dodd, Mead and Co.

div.head: SUDAN PROGRESS.
div.p: SIR R: SLATIN INTERVIEWED.
Reuter's representative has had an inter view with General Sir Rudolf Slatin (Inspector General of the Sudan), who is on a short visit to this country.

Speaking of the position in the Sudan he said: "The position of affairs is entirely satisfactory, financially and politically. The revenue shows an annual increase, and this without having recourse to increased taxation In fact, on the contrary, we are trying om best to reduce taxes where possible.
The people generally are satisfied, and if as sometimes happens, new laws have to be • enacted which go against their traditions, they
realise that they are for the public good, and cheerfully sıbmit.

One of the most important signs in the Sudan is the remarkable increase of popula tion, and by this I do not inean the removal of people from other regions, but the great increase in the number of children, which is åt inost hopeful sign for the future of the country. The people are most anxions to have their children educated, and a satisfactory proof of their confidence is that they are sending so many that the applications are more numerons than our schools are able to accept. The Gordon College is already bearing good fruit, as the Government is being supplied there with land surveyors, &c.'

Dealing with the native situation, Sir Rudolf said : "The tribes are peaceful. Of course, inter-tribal questions and jealousies arise when it is necessary for the Government to keep · der ; but there is nothing to give rise to any anxiety. With regard to the Senussi movement, this has very little influence in the Sudan. It has a certain weight in Egypt, but it is chiefly in Darfur and the west. In the Sudan it is practically nil."

Asked about the recent manifestation of the Pan-Islamic movement, Sir Rudolf said that it was a very dificult question to discuss, but added that he did not consider the people of Egypt or the Sudan were fanatical.

"One must always remember," he added, "that they belong to a different religion from our own, and that in Egypt, particularly people who are discontented with the Government, are always ready to use their religion to stir up the population against their rulers."
On the subject of general development Sir Rudolf Slatin said:

"New commercial stations have been opened, one leading to the Blue Nile and one on the Baro, and trade is beginning to flow from Abyssinia to the Sudan by this means Of course, at the beginning it is slow, but great development may be looked for. We are on good terms with the Abyssinians. although occasionally there is trouble with raiders who are outlaws in Abyssinian ter ritory.

"As regards water communication, we are improving the rivers in every way we can We continue to clear the sudd, and dredger have been ordered for deepening the chan nels. The Atbara-Port Sudan Railway is working most satisfactorily, and trade along this route is increasing.
"We are now engaged in building a bridge over the Blue Nile at Khartoum and extend ing the railways through the fertile country between the White and Blue Niles.

"There is no necessity to construct a rail way connecting the Sudan with Uganda whil there is a splendid waterway to Gondokoro We must, of course, have a line of communica tion from north to south, but there is n necessity for a Cape to Cairo railway on thi section while we have better and cheape transit by boat."
"With regard to motor traffic in the fa away districts of Bahr-el-Ghazal and Souther Kordofan, roads are being made and improve so that motor lorries can be employed." .

Concerning the situation at the Lad Enclave, Sir Rudolf said that the relatior between the Anglo-Egyptian and Congo Fre State Governments were friendly, as the latte had evacuated the territory claimed by th former. ("Financial News.")

div.head: "TO EMPIRE VIA DENSHAWAI."
div.p: * (From The New Age.) Just about a year ago a party of British officers got mixed up in a village row at Denshawai, in Egypt. They had gone to amuse themselves by shooting pigeons, the domesticated pigeons of the villagers, and had apparently not been | careful to get permission. By accident an
Egyptian woman got wounded, the officers were mobbed and lost their heads, two of them ran for help while three were beaten by the crowd, and one of those who ran dropped dead.

Now it does not need a very profound knowledge of the psychology of the British officer to recognise in this incident all his characteristic bravado and stopidity. The | officers had not taken the trouble to either understand the language or the humanity of the villagers, who were treated as creatures of another species.

Consequently at the first sign of the breakdown of the formal nexus of behaviour which enables the British officer to communicate with the Egyptian village, the officers were hopelessly bewildered, lost their heads and gave way to panic.

Had there been anyone at headquarters to put the matter right by a stiff reprimand, matters would have been no more serious than a schoolboy's row with a gamekeeper. But apparently those at headquarters got even more panic-stricken than the officers, and without the excuse of the hubbub and turmoil of a riot, gave fanatic orders for arrest and trial of the riotous villagers 1 As a result four men were hanged, and eight men were flogged and some imprisoned.
On the face of it, this story sounds incredible ; one imagines there must be something more behind it. That something more, accordJing to Lords Cromer and Grey, is an Egyptian
National movement which has to be sternly suppressed.

But even granting that there is an Egyptian Nationalist movement, is there any evidence at all that the mobbing of soine stupid men at Denshawai had anything to do with it ? In fact, there is no justification whatsoever for this belief, there are no reasons, only motives, and the motives are those of bewildered fear.

Now, even if Denshawai were a separate incident, it would be a very serious matter to recognise that our administration in Egypt is so fatally wrong-headed. Whatever other conclusions we may draw, it is at least certain that out administrators, do not understand the | temperament of the people they are governing.
The question becomes, have they made any | effort to understand ? How many, for instance,
of those officials who are thrown into contact | with the people of the country can understand
their language or are versed in the etiquette of their social life?
In South Africa many Boers keep their hats on their heads when they enter a room and expectorate at leisure on the carpet. This conduct would be considered a little ontra in London.

Is it not perhaps possible our officials transgress in an equally serious manner? Is there, indeed, any adequate provision to prevent such possible offences ? T'he shooting of domesticated pigeons does not sound as if there were.

The matter, however, is by no means confined to the one incident. The Denshawai picnic is diagnostic of the most serious imperial disease-ccmplacent failure to understand. One can parallel it almost detail for detail in the incidents which occurred before the late Natal campaign ; the failure to understand, the refusal to try to understand, the sudden panic of minor officials spreading up into the central administration; the harsh measures of retribution, the imagination of a big national| ist "Ethiopian" movement. All these things were parts of the Richmond incident which precipitated the Natal campaign.

If an administration will only go on irritating a people, whom it does not understand, long enough, if it will only go on telling them they are dangerous traitors nursing nationalist dreams, that people will come to believe and act upon the Government's suggestions. The question finally is one of the possibility of zavoiding this kind of stupidity.

Empire has no meaning for a Socialist, unless it means the co-operation of autonomous units. Can we understand and co-operate with the Egyptian people and with the other alien races within our boundaries? If we are to do so it will need a very much greater effort to understand, and it will mean that our administrators sball be really compelled to study the language, habits, and customs of the people amongst whoin they are going at first hand. And this means in all probability the scrapping of a good deal of our upper-class public schoolboy machinery in favour of a school-board polytechnic-educated human being.
The time, indeed, may not be far distant when we shall be compelled to insist on the public-school coming up to a decent educational standard.

From the national point of view that is, and not their class point of view. When one reads in the Blue books that in the Denshawai hangings and floggings "all possible humanity was shown," and "the arrangements reflected great credit on all concerned," and then parallel this with a quotation from the Natal shooting correspondence where a clergyman of the Church of England certifies that the men were shot "with the utmost humanity," it is clear that the disease is deep-seated.
Unless our administrators can realise that other races and classes are human beings, and can understand them as human beings, there is no future for our Empire.
Meanwhile there are some Denshawai natives still in prison. We have made them our enemies, that is the worst of stupidity, but there is no reason why they should be kept there any longer.

We are glad to see that a petition signed by Egyptian notables was presented to the Khedive on June 28, the anniversary of the "hanging" incident; and we hope that the petition will be supported by questions in the House of Commons..

div.head: MANCHESTER GOODS.
div.p: TRADE WITH EGYPT.

It was hoped at one time, says the "Monthly Journal" of the British Chamber of Commerce for Egypt, that the financial crisis through which we are passing would not affect to any appreciable extent this branch of the import trade, piece goods dealers, as a rule, being free from any desire to purchase stocks and shares ; but the suspension of the Cassa di Sconto has quite dissipated that hope, as this establishment appears to have been in direct financial relation with various firms interested in the trade. Business during the month of June has been extremely quiet. A few small sales of cheap goods may have been made; a few orders for the season may have been booked : and that is about all that can be reported. No revival is likely to take place until the present uneasiness and want of confidence have passed away. :

div.head: PLAGUE IN INDIA
div.p: The following mortality following the out| break of plague in India is shown by figures
furnished by the India Office in reply to a parliamentary question.
In 1896 there were 1,704. deaths, but in | the following year the record leaped to 56,000.
For two years the rate of increase was almost as heavy up to 1900, when there was a lull. But it was only temporary.
During 1904 over a million deaths were recorded, and this year, for the first five months, the appalling total is 991,003.
Since 1896 five and in half million deaths have occurred.

... ....... 116,936 .1906 ... ... , 204,640 In 1906 the imports were derived as follows - United Kingdom, L.E. 184,223 ; Switzer. land, L.E. 21,961 ; Germany, L.E. 11,824 Ainerica, L.E. 11,439; France, L.E. 3,800 other countries, L.E. 1,387. Egypt is essential ly an agricultural country, and the Sudar appears likely to become one, so in the near future trade in agricultural machinery is bound to develop still more. At the present time ir Egypt ont of an area of nine million feddans only six millions are under crop, the remaining three million feddans will be cultivated wher the schemes of irrigation drawn up by th Government have been realised.

Schemes are also on foot for largely increas ing the agricultural resources of the Sudan and this will naturally lead to a large demand for the necessary implements. div.head: TRADE IN THE LEVANT.
div.p: OUR RIVALS IN TURKEY.

"Trade with Turkey" was the subject of an address given at a special meeting of the London Chamber of Commerce last week by Mr. A. T. Waugh, British Consul at Constantinople. The President (Sir Albert Spicer, M.P.) explained that Mr. Waugh was present in accordance with the comparatively recent but excellent idea of the Foreign Office and the Board of Trade that British commercial representatives abroad should, when in this country, pay visits to the more important commercial centres for the purpose of consultation with business men. Mr. Waugh said that fifty years ago our manufacturers and merchants had no rivals in Turkey, but now only 37 per cent. of the total imports of that country were British. We ought to do better. The Turks were changing their ideas and habits. What we called civilisation was creeping in. They were learning to use foreign goods, only slowly at present, but the change might become rapid. German trade with Turkey was growing very fast, thanks to subsidised steamships, the establishment of banks, the building of railways, and other means. The Germans were sparing no efforts to secure Turkish trade, of the value of which they were fully convinced. Italians, too, were making great commercial progress in the Sultan's dominions. It would be worth our while to learn from these competitors, and we must do so if we wanted even to hold oar own. For one thing he personally desired co-operation ; that was the school opened in Constantinople two years ago to educate the sons of British parents. The boys were being specially trained for business | life in Turkey, and of course they learned to read and write the native language, an accomplishment of which most foreign residents were extremely ignorant. The school was a tardy attempt to do for Britain what every other Great Power had already done in Turkeyfoster a resident colony of its subjects. As for the 3 per cent, which the Macedonian Agree ment permitted the Sultan to add to the import duties, the effect would not be great. Turkey, being the only Free Trade country apart from our own, would take all the foreign goods she wanted, whether the duties were 8 or 11 per cent.

div.head: CHIEF RABBI'S HINT TO SCOTLAND.
div.p: Dr. Adler, Chief Rabbi of the United Hebrew congregations of Great Britain, 'has been paying an official visit to Scotland, and, according to the "Scottish Review," he administered one or two hard knocks.

Referring to the General Assemblies, Dr. Adler said it grieved him to read about missions to convert the Jews in face of the terrible amount of vice and drunkenness and irreligion prevailing among their own co-religionists and fellow citizens. Surely there was sufficient work for these minister to do without attempting the conversion of the Jews, and surely they ought to know what enormous sacrifice Jews in Scotland were making to preserve houses of prayer.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie hier après-midi sous la présidence de Schiess Pacha

--- Communication a été donnée d'une lettre du Ministère de l'Intérieur suspendant, en vue de l'examen par les services intéressés, la déci sion prise par la Commission Municipale relative au règlement pour le stationnement des barq nes au Canal Mahmoudieh et celle relative à la concession de la jetée promenade à M. J Joseph.
Lo Ministère a approuvé, d'autre part, les divers crédits votés par la Commission Mu nicipale dans sa dernière séance.

--- La Délégation demandera à la Commission l'ouverture des crédits nécessaires pour l'aména gement des bureaux de la Municipalité pa suite de la construction des nouvelles annexes ainsi que pour l'installation de nouvelles bou ches d incendies au Palais Municipal. Elle demandera également le crédit nécessaire pou la fourniture de nouvelles plaques pour le cochers, dont le prix sera ensuite rembours par ces derniers.

- Sur la proposition de la Direction générale des services sanitaires, la Municipalité prendra les mesures nécessaires pour assurer l'importation dans de bonnes conditions et son transport au Caire par chemin de fer, du bétail de Bulgarie. On adoptera les mêmes mesures que pour le transport du bétail de Serbie.

-Le Délégation & Sutorisé le Comité de l'Hôpital des Diaconesses à installer une voi Decauville du côté des prisons de Hadra, pou faciliter le transport du matériel servant à la construction du nouvel hôpital.

- Elle a adjugé à M. Enriquez la construc tion de deux rues à San Stefano ; à M. Caricato Giovanni le dallage de la route du Mex jusqu'au second bloc de tanneries et à MM. Saoulli e Robert la fourniture de tuyaux en grès syphons et coudes.
- Après examen des plans soumis par l'in génieur en chef relativement à l'emplacemen du nouveau Théâtre, la Délégation est d'avis d'ajourner la décision jusqu'à la rentrée.

-- Le Gouvernement ayant demandé de nou veau l'alignement des terrains au Rond-Poin pour la construction des nouvelles Ecoles pri maires indigènes pour les garçons et filles, la Délégation a décidé de tenter une dernir démarche auprès du Ministère pour qu'il choi sisse un autre emplacement, de préférence du côté de Ras-el-Tin. La Délégation serait mêm disposée de donner en échange au Gouverne ment un terrain sur les nouveaux quais du côte d'Anfouchi.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourdhui à midi). Les mauvaises nouvelles qui nous sont arri vées du Caire concernant plusieurs dépôts de bilan ont exercé ici une infinence des plus défavorables. Presqire toute la cote est en baisse.

Parmi les valeurs dirigeantes, l'Agricole recule de 75'8 à 7 1/2, la National Bank de 18 15/16 à 18 1/2, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 309 l'ancienne et 261 la nouvelle à 305 et 259 respectivement; seule la Delta Light bénéficie de 1/16 à 9 3/8.

En baisse encore la Ramleh de 4 3/4 à 4 11/16, les Privilégiées Tramways de 150 à 145, la Daïra de 13 3/8 à 13 1/4, la Béhéra de 25 à 24-1/2, les Lots Turcs de 164 à 163, la Banque d'Athènes de 113 1/2 à 112, la Land Bank de 7 à 6 7/8, les Splendid Hotels de 4 1/8 à 4, l'Urbaine de 3 3/4 à 3 11/16, l'Union Foncière de 4 3/4 à 4 11/16, le Crédit FrancoEgyptien de 4 1[16 à 4, la Banque d'Orient de 114 1/2 à 112.

La Deferred Delta perd 2 livres et demie à 3 1/2, les Nungovich Hotels 1 livre à 15, les Sucreries 10 francs à 40, la Land Investment 1/2 livre et 1 livre respectivement à 4 1/2 l'action et 5 la fondateur.
Parmi les petites valeurs la Salt and Soda Aéchit de 16 à 15/6, la Delta Land de 1 5/16 à 1 3/16, la Port Said Salt de 14 à 13,'6 et la fondateur United de 1 3/4 à 1 1/2.

Font seuls exception au désarroi général les Markets qui remontent de 25/3 à 26, le Comptoir Financier de 2 1/8 l'ancienne et 2 la nouvelle à 2 3/8 et 2 1/4 respectivement, et la Building Lands de 2 à 2 1/16.

La vente aux enchères qui nous avons annonoće bier, s'est, parait-il, effectuée assez facilement, bien entendu à des coors légèrement inférieurs. Il est vrai qu'il s'agissait de quantités peu considérables. Il nous revient que d'autres veptes bien plus importantes auront lieu prochainement.

On a beaucoup traité depuis quelques jours, ce matin en particulier, les obligations Crédit Foncier, anciennes et nouvelles. Les détenteurs trop chargés et éprouvés par la baisse les vendent pour équilibrer leur marge.
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Mardi 16 juillet. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres s'est maintenu hier à 3 5/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a avancé de 1/8 à 84 3/4. L'Unifiée 'a haussé de 1/4 à 101 1/4. La National Bank a rétrogradé de 1/4 à 19 1/8. L'Agricole est restée in variée à 7 3/4, de même que la Daïra Sanieh à 13 1/2 et la Delta Light à 9 3/8.
A Paris, la Bourse est restée fermée hier à l'occasion du lendemain de la fête nationale du 14 Juillet

La nouvelle baisse de la National Bank a Londres, jointe à la propagation sur place de toutes sortes de racontars, a influé aujourd'hui défavorablement sur notre marché des valeurs. D'où un nouveau tassement sur la plupart des cours. Il importe peut-être de ne pas perdre de vne que le recul de la National Bank est dn a des ventes à terme, qui, comme en Juin dermier, pourraient bien finir par créer un découvert et déterminer une forte reprise à l'approche de la liquidation de fin de mois. Pour ce qui est des informations pessimistes, elles se rapportent simplement à des affaires d'ordre pour ainsi dire rétrospectif, dont les principales sont en voie d'arrangement. Il n'y a donc pas lieu de s'émouvoir outre mesure de ces maneuvres du parti baissier. Il suffirait de bien peu de chose pour amener un revirement subit.
En attendant, la National Bank a Aéchi, sans opérations importantes, à 18 15/16. L'Agricole s'est tassée à 7 5/8-11/16. Les parts de la Société Générale Egyptienne ont été négoriées à 33.

Le Crédit Foncier a été delaissé à 680 ; l'obligation à lots ancienne est revenue à 307308. La Béhéra a été cotée 19 3/4 ex-right. Les parts de fondateur Société Immobilière d'Egypte sont tombées à 460 et celles de l'Enterprise and Development à 11. L'Union Foncière a décliné à 4 5/8.

La Delta Light a progressé à 9 5/16. Les Héliopolis ont été traitées à 236 ; leur part a avancé à 10. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont reculé à 170. La Brasserie des Pyramides a faibli à 85. Les Menzaleh ont été tenues à 3 1/2.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont clôturé à 15. En bonne tendance, les Egyptian ont atteint 5 1/2 pour finir à 5 3/8-7/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été cotés 1 7/16 ex-coupon. Les Estates se sont raffermis à 0 11/16.3/4. ,

Après une discussion fort animée, l'assemblée générale extraordinaire de l'Association des courtiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie a adopté hier les mesures proposées par le comité de l'Association relativement à la suite à donner aux transactions pratiquées en actions Bourse and Banking Ltd. -

Les opérations faites à £ 1 et au-dessus seront réglées et liquidées par le simple paiement de la différence,sans livraisons des titres. Les opérations au-dessous de £ 1 seront extournées au prix auquel elles ont été faites. Les premiers souscripteurs demeureront ainsi les propriétaires des actions.
L'assemblée a ensuite élu MM. J.G. Bekhyt, J. P. Rodocanaki et F. S. Rossano membres du Comité de l'Association, en remplacement de MM. D. Klat, P. Angustino et J. Arditi, démissionnaires.
wres.

L'assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Société Générale Egyptienne pour l'Agricul. ture et le Commerce, tenue ces jours derniers à Bruxelles, a pris connaissance de l'acte enregistré le 15 Avril 1907, d'où il résulte :

1°. Que le capital a été porté à 25 millions de francs par la création de 40,000 nouvelles actions de capital et que le nombre des parts de fondateur a été porté à son maximum de 7,500 ; 2° Que 30,000 de ces nouvelles actions de capital ont été souscrites; 3o que les 10,000 nctions de capital nouvelles restantes ont été attribuées à la Société en commandite par actions Rom, Van der Linden et Cie en rémunération de l'apport de ses maisons du Caire et d'Alexandrie.
L'assemblée a ensuite élu MM. J.G. Bekhyt, J. P. Rodocanaki et F. S. Rossano membres du Comité de l'Association, en remplacement de MM. D. Klat, P. Augustino et J. Arditi, démissionnaires.

L'assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Société Générale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce, tenue ces jours derniers à Bruxelles, a pris connaissance de l'acte enregistré le 15 Avril 1907, d'où il résulte :

1°. Que le capital a été porté à 25 millions de francs par la création de 40,000 nouvelles actions de capital et que le nombre des parts de fondateur a été porté à son maximum de 7,500 ; 2° Que 30,000 de ces nouvelles actions de capital ont été souscrites; 3o que les 10,000 actions de capital nouvelles restantes ont été attribuées à la Société en commandite par actions Rom, Van der Linden et Cie en rémunération de l'apport de ses maisons du Caire et d'Alexandrie.

L'assemblée a appronvé le dit apport et sa rémunération en actions de capital, ainsi que l'attribution des parts de fondateur. Elle a antorisé ensuite le conseil d'administration à augmenter le capital de 10 millions de francs et de le porter ainsi, en une ou plusieurs fois, de 25 à 35 millions de francs par l'émission de nouvelles actions de capital, soit contre espèces, soit contre apports.
L'assemblée a voté les modifications aux statuts résultant de ces résolutions.

Par suite de nouvelles nominations faites, le conseil d'administration est actuellement composé de MM. E. Thys, président, F. Jacobs fils, L. Van der Bosch, C. Scheidt, A. Curphey, A. Van der Linden et F. Romn, administrateurdélégué.
On mande de Constantinople, à la date du 10 Juillet :

"Lie Trésor turc a de plus en plus besoin d'argent. Après les avances successives, dont il a été parlé ces derniers temps, de la Banque Impériale Ottomane et de nombreux autres prêteurs, on annonce comme prochaine l'émission d'une partie de l'emprunt 1904 de deux et demi millions de livres turques. Il s'agit d'un emprunt dit "du timbre" mais gagé sur les excedents de la Dette publique et prévu par le décret-annexe publié lors de l'unification de la Dette. Le gage consiste dans les 75 % revenant au gouvernement, turc de l'excédent des recettes au-delà de £2,157,375 nécessaires au service de la Dette privilégiée, des Lots et de la Dette entière. Cet excédent s'élèverait cette année à L.T. 393,015, ce qui donnerait pour la part du Trésor L.T. 294,762 pouvant servir de gage à l'emprunt. Déjà l'année dernière à pareille époque il a été parlé de ce projet d'emprunt. Il est vraisem. blable que la Banque Ottomane a fait an Trésor diverses avances gagées sur ces excédents, et peut-être s'agit-il aujourd'hui de ces petits prêts successifs en même temps que de l'émission du solde de l'opération."

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
